The other option for white is 5. Bb5
The other option for white is 5. Bb5

5. ... Qa5+ was also playable but white can play 6.Nc3 which gives the knight a good place and doesn't lose a tempo. Then, the black queen can easily be fired by 6. b4. 5. ... e6 is playable as well but I thought that my LSB would be blocked and I didn't like this idea.
pinning the knight.
Now I can play e6 without blocking my LSB. My plan is to set the g knight on e7 and to fiancheto y DSB, so that black would have a very good defense and counterattacking possibilities toward e5.

The c pawn is here to stay  but my plan is to develop and menace the e pawn with my fianchetoed DSB. Since white will probably castle short, the e pawn will be hard to defend, except by playing f4, which will weaken the white queen.
To prepare Bg7.  With the g knight on e7, black should have a good defense.

Only 2 more moves and black's developpement will be completed. (O-O and Qc7). I think that the position shall be really good.

White seems to share this opinion and prevents my fine developpement. If we trade black's 2 bishops against white's 2 knights, which I cannot prevent, black's counterattacking possibiities will be considerably weakened but white will find it difficult to attack my fiancheto without DSB, so that I might obtain a draw even considering white's pawn advance.
No choice
No choice
No choice
Puting the King in safety and preparing Re1
Menacing Nxe5

So, it's done. Black is better on the center but black can contest it. White is ahead in material (one pawn), both Kings are safe, there is no immediate threat and no open line. Black's pawn structure is better. White can improve his but he will have to weaken his king. White has still the initiative. With this pawn disposition, a bishop is better than a knight. The situation seems equilibrated.

Porbably to protect b4 and, more important, to reinforce d4 which might become an essential square, later in the game, the drawback being having an unprotected c pawn on black's DSB diagonal where the black queen could soon come. Anyway, black cannot prevent f6. Now I see 2 possible plans for black : whether defend on the left wing (playing Rfb8 or a6), or attack on the center, attacking the e pawn by f6 or with a previous Qc7. I hesitate a bit. Anyway, this game is already a good point for me, because it's the first time that I can envisage an attacking strategy with black, against a master, with a reasonable chance of success.
Finally, I opt for this move : the queen protects the a7 and c6 pawn, two of the weak points of black's dispositive and menaces e5, one of the weak points of black's one.
It seemed evident that I had to set a rook on b8 but which one ? I choosed the f one because I supposed that my opponent would attack on the queenside but was not sure at all.
